response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "This measure establishes requirements for kauhale projects, including reporting requirements by the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions (OHHS). [CHUNK_56] It also establishes the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program within OHHS and appropriates funds for the continued implementation of both the Kauhale Initiative and the Ohana Zones Program. [CHUNK_63] The measure requires the Auditor to conduct a management and performance audit of the kauhale initiative and changes the reporting structure for the Coordinator on Homelessness. [CHUNK_56] [CHUNK_58]",
  "appropriations": "The measure appropriates out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $18,575,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $24,325,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_14] For the continued implementation of the ohana zones program, the measure appropriates $2,525,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $5,855,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_35] [CHUNK_36] All sums appropriated shall be expended by the department of human services. [CHUNK_16] [CHUNK_36]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The fiscal projections are based on specific appropriation amounts inserted into the bill for the continued operation of two existing programs. [CHUNK_65] [CHUNK_66] The sums are intended to cover expenses including the development and operation of facilities, support services, staffing, and other costs associated with alleviating poverty and transitioning individuals into housing. [CHUNK_15] [CHUNK_16] [CHUNK_34] The fiscal note assumes these amounts are sufficient for the purposes described for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [CHUNK_14] [CHUNK_36]",
  "agency_impact": "The sums appropriated for the kauhale initiative and ohana zones program shall be expended by the department of human services. [CHUNK_16] [CHUNK_37] The bill specifies that the Coordinator on Homelessness shall report directly to the Director of Human Services, altering the previous administrative structure. [CHUNK_54] [CHUNK_69] The Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions is tasked with new, extensive reporting requirements, including quarterly expenditure reports and a comprehensive needs assessment. [CHUNK_37] [CHUNK_39]",
  "economic_impact": "The measure aims to address the basic needs of individuals experiencing homelessness and transition them into affordable housing. [CHUNK_34] Kauhale projects are authorized to charge monthly rents that do not exceed thirty per cent of the area median income, which will directly affect the finances of residents. [CHUNK_2] The programs provide wrap-around services, social and health care services, and transportation with the goal of alleviating poverty. [CHUNK_34]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure establishes the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program, shifting it from its previous pilot status. [CHUNK_57] [CHUNK_66] It modifies existing law by changing references from the \"Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness\" to \"Coordinator on Homelessness\" and specifying that the coordinator reports to the Director of Human Services. [CHUNK_58] [CHUNK_69] The bill also imposes new statutory requirements for kauhale projects and mandates a management and performance audit of the kauhale initiative by the State Auditor. [CHUNK_64] [CHUNK_65]",
  "revenue_sources": "The appropriations for the kauhale initiative and ohana zones program are from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35] A potential new revenue stream is created through the provision that the monthly rent charged to any resident of a kauhale shall not exceed thirty per cent of the area median income. [CHUNK_2] No other revenue sources are identified in the measure. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure appropriates a total of $42,900,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for the kauhale initiative and $8,380,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt) for the ohana zones program over fiscal years 2025-2027. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35] For the kauhale initiative, the bill appropriates $18,575,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $24,325,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_65] For the ohana zones program, the appropriation is $2,525,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $5,855,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_66] The establishment of the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program implies an ongoing fiscal commitment beyond the initial two-year appropriation. [CHUNK_66] The description of the kauhale initiative funding as for \"continued operation\" suggests recurring expenses in future years. [CHUNK_14] The mandatory management audit and new reporting requirements will create additional administrative costs for the Auditor's office and the Department of Human Services. [CHUNK_12] [CHUNK_37] Given the permanence of one program and the continuation of the other, similar levels of funding will likely be required in the subsequent four years to maintain program operations and services. [CHUNK_14] [CHUNK_66]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The measure authorizes a source of operating revenue for kauhale projects. [CHUNK_11] The bill specifies that the monthly rent charged to any resident of a kauhale shall not exceed thirty per cent of the area median income. [CHUNK_2] This provision could provide a recurring revenue stream to help offset the operational costs of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_11]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "Funds are appropriated for the development and operation of kauhale. [CHUNK_14] The bill mandates that any kauhale projects constructed or developed using state funds shall be connected to public utilities, including water, sewer, and electricity, which will involve capital costs. [CHUNK_2] The bill also establishes a requirement of at least two bidders for any kauhale project estimated to be over $1,000,000 (HB431_CD1_.HTM.txt), indicating that significant capital projects are anticipated. [CHUNK_3]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "By establishing the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program, the measure creates an ongoing fiscal obligation for the State beyond the six-year horizon. [CHUNK_57] [CHUNK_66] Continued funding will be necessary to sustain the operations, staffing, and support services for both the permanent Ohana Zones Program and the continued Kauhale Initiative. [CHUNK_14] [CHUNK_18] The annual reporting requirements for both programs also imply sustained administrative costs in future years. [CHUNK_8] [CHUNK_31]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This version of the bill specifies appropriation amounts, which were previously unspecified; it appropriates $18,575,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) in FY26 and $24,325,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) in FY27 for the Kauhale Initiative, and $2,525,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) in FY26 and $5,855,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) in FY27 for Ohana Zones. [CHUNK_65] [CHUNK_66] The Ohana Zones Pilot Program has been established as a permanent program. [CHUNK_66] New reporting requirements have been added, requiring OHHS to report to the legislature every four months and conduct a comprehensive needs assessment, and requiring the Auditor to conduct a management and performance audit of the Kauhale Initiative. [CHUNK_64] [CHUNK_68] Language that would have appropriated funds for supportive housing projects was deleted. [CHUNK_67] The Coordinator on Homelessness now reports directly to the Director of Human Services instead of the Governor. [CHUNK_69] The effective date was changed from a defective date to July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_69]",
  "fte_positions": "The appropriation for the kauhale initiative includes funding for staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_15] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the department of human services. [CHUNK_16] The measure does not specify the number of Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions to be funded. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35]",
  "appropriations_changes": "Appropriation amounts that were previously unspecified have been inserted into the measure. [CHUNK_65] [CHUNK_66] The bill now appropriates specific sums for the Kauhale Initiative ($18,575,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $24,325,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027) and the Ohana Zones Program ($2,525,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $5,855,000 (HB431_CD1_CCR189_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027). [CHUNK_65] [CHUNK_66] Additionally, the committee deleted language that would have appropriated funds for supportive housing projects and supportive services. [CHUNK_67]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The funding source for all appropriations remains the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35] The provision allowing kauhale to charge rent of no more than thirty per cent of the area median income continues to be a potential supplemental revenue source. [CHUNK_2] There have been no changes to the primary method of funding between bill versions. [CHUNK_13] [CHUNK_35]",
  "department_impact": "While the expending agency remains the Department of Human Services as in the prior version, this measure further impacts the department's administrative structure. [CHUNK_16] [CHUNK_36] It specifies that the Coordinator on Homelessness, who heads the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions, shall report directly to the Director of Human Services. [CHUNK_54] [CHUNK_69] This is a change from the previous structure where the coordinator reported to the Governor. [CHUNK_54]",
  "reports_required": "This measure adds several new reporting requirements that were not in the previous version. [CHUNK_64] The coordinator on homelessness must submit annual reports to the legislature on both the kauhale and ohana zones programs. [CHUNK_8] [CHUNK_31] The statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions must submit a report to the legislature every four months detailing expenditures and a separate report on a comprehensive needs assessment by the 2026 regular session. [CHUNK_37] [CHUNK_40] The auditor is required to submit a management and performance audit of the kauhale initiative to the legislature prior to the 2026 regular session. [CHUNK_12]",
  "pilot_program": "A significant change from the previous version is that the Ohana Zones Program is now established as a permanent program. [CHUNK_57] The bill establishes within the office the ohana zones program to provide temporary housing and services to homeless individuals and families. [CHUNK_18] The appropriation is for the continued implementation of the program, which was originally established as a pilot under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018. [CHUNK_36]",
  "sunset_date": "The provided documents do not contain a sunset date for the appropriations or the programs. [CHUNK_55] The measure establishes the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program, implying no sunset. [CHUNK_57]",
  "effective_date": "The effective date has been changed to July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_69] This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_55]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB431 CD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 2 C.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. Chapter 346, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is

PART I SECTION 1. Chapter 346, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding two new sections to subpart B of part XVIII to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " § 346- Kauhale projects; requirements. (a) Any kauhale projects constructed or developed using state funds shall be connected

projects constructed or developed using state funds shall be connected to public utilities, including water, sewer, and electricity. (b) The monthly rent charged to any resident of a kauhale shall not exceed thirty per cent of the area median income. (c) If funds appropriated for construction and development of a

(c) If funds appropriated for construction and development of a kauhale project are used to contract for the procurement of building services and projects related to the kauhale initiative, there shall be at least two bidders for any kauhale project estimated to be over $1,000,000. (d) The office shall conduct

estimated to be over $1,000,000. (d) The office shall conduct and complete a community consultation process prior to the construction and development of any kauhale project. (e) Should any portion of the funds appropriated for the construction of a kauhale project be used for purposes inconsistent with the intent of

project be used for purposes inconsistent with the intent of the kauhale initiative or the construction is phased out and the kauhale project is contracted with a private entity, the State shall have the first right to recoup and reclaim all or a portion of the appropriated funds. § 346-

all or a portion of the appropriated funds. § 346- Kauhale; reports. (a) The office shall establish the following: (1) The evaluation criteria and process that the office shall use each year when reviewing the success and sustainability of the kauhale; and (2) Monitoring and oversight controls over the kauhale

kauhale; and (2) Monitoring and oversight controls over the kauhale to identify, address, and prevent possible fraud, waste, and abuse and ensure compliance with federal, state, and local laws. (b) The coordinator shall compile and consolidate information from the office and submit a report to the legislature no later than

and submit a report to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session, which shall include: (1) Data on the number of beds, occupancy, duration of stay, types of services provided, and next planned destination of participants who left the kauhale; (2) An

planned destination of participants who left the kauhale; (2) An evaluation of the kauhale to determine whether the objectives set have been met or exceeded; and (3) Any proposed changes that need to be made to the performance measures used to assess the achievement of program goals. " SECTION 2

to assess the achievement of program goals. " SECTION 2 . Section 346-385, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new definition to be appropriately inserted and to read as follows: " "Kauhale" means: (1) A program to address the basic needs of individuals experiencing houselessness; and (2) Affordable

the basic needs of individuals experiencing houselessness; and (2) Affordable housing spaces that are communal living spaces with individual household units and charge monthly rents no more than thirty per cent of the area median income level. " SECTION 3 . (a) The auditor shall conduct a management and performance

. (a) The auditor shall conduct a management and performance audit of the kauhale initiative. (b) The auditor shall submit the audit with any findings and recommendations, including any proposed legislation, to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026. SECTION

to the convening of the regular session of 2026. SECTION 4. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $18,575,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $24,325,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary

and $24,325,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative , including expenses related to: (1) The development and operation of kauhale; (2) The provision of project-based rent supplement payments; (3) The provision of support services for qualified

supplement payments; (3) The provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale; (4) Staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative; (5) Addressing basic needs of individuals and families experiencing homelessness; (6) Wrap around services; (7) Social and health care services; (8) Transportation; and (9) Other

Social and health care services; (8) Transportation; and (9) Other services with the goal of alleviating poverty and transitioning individuals and families experiencing homelessness or housing instability into supportive or affordable housing. The sums appropriated shall be expended by the department of human services for the purposes of this part.

follows: " § 346- Ohana zones program; establishment; reports. (a) There is established within the office the ohana zones program to provide temporary housing and services to homeless individuals and families based on principles similar to the housing first program. (b) The office shall determine the number and locations of

(b) The office shall determine the number and locations of ohana zone sites, which shall be situated on public or private lands in accordance with subsection (c). (c) The office may coordinate with public or private entities, as appropriate, to develop and implement the ohana zones program; provided that: (1)

develop and implement the ohana zones program; provided that: (1) If any public land under the jurisdiction of a state or county agency is determined to be suitable for use as an ohana zone, the office shall: (A) Work with the appropriate state or county agency that controls the land

the appropriate state or county agency that controls the land to transfer the land designated for use as an ohana zone to an agency whose mission is more suited to the management of ohana zones; and (B) Work with the appropriate state or county agency that controls the land and

appropriate state or county agency that controls the land and its construction agency to ensure that an ohana zone's infrastructure needs are met and minimize adverse impacts to the environment, including to nearshore resources, such as corals, reef fish, and seabirds; (2) Use of any private lands determined to be

seabirds; (2) Use of any private lands determined to be suitable for use as an ohana zone shall be for limited purposes and require a written agreement between the private land owner and any state or county agency that any structure built with public funds may be moved or is

structure built with public funds may be moved or is temporary; provided further that if the land ceases to be used for an ohana zone or low-income housing before the time specified in the agreement, the state or county agency may choose to move the structure off the private land

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

Report Title: DHS; OHHS; Housing; Kauhale Initiative; Ohana Zones Pilot Program; Reporting; Auditor; Coordinator on Homelessness; Director of Human Services; Appropriations Description: Part I: Establishes requirements for kauhale projects, including reporting requirements by the Statewide Office

for kauhale projects, including reporting requirements by the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions (OHHS). Requires the Auditor to conduct a management and performance audit of the kauhale initiative. Appropriates funds for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative. Part II: Establishes the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent

Part II: Establishes the Ohana Zones Program as a permanent program within OHHS. Appropriates funds to DHS for the continued implementation of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program. Part III: Requires OHHS to submit a report every four months to the Legislature detailing the expenditure of funds appropriated toward the kauhale

Legislature detailing the expenditure of funds appropriated toward the kauhale and ohana zones initiatives and conduct a comprehensive needs assessment. Part IV: Changes references to the Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness to "Coordinator on Homelessness". Specifies that the Coordinator on Homelessness shall report directly to the Director of Human Services. (CD1)

bill in an amended form. The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for: (1) The continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program; and (2) The development of supportive housing projects and the provision of supportive services for certain households in the supportive housing projects.

supportive services for certain households in the supportive housing projects. of the Ohana Zones Pilot Program; (6) Deleting language that would have appropriated funds for supportive housing projects and supportive services for certain households in those projects; (7) Requiring the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions to submit a report every four months to the Legislature detailing the expenditure

report every four months to the Legislature detailing the expenditure of funds appropriated toward the Kauhale and Ohana Zones initiatives and conduct a comprehensive needs assessment and submit a report on the assessment to the Legislature; (8) Changing references to the Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness to "Coordinator on Homelessness"; (9)

the Governor's Coordinator on Homelessness to "Coordinator on Homelessness"; (9) Specifying that the Coordinator on Homelessness shall report directly to the Director of Human Services; (10) Changing the effective date to July 1, 2025; and (11) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity, consistency, and style.
